comment.body: 似乎是有一个两年前的Google+帖子被找出来，里面介绍SSR的时候说是由misakamm开发的。后面的信息应该都是misakamm的，至于和breakwa11是不是一个人就没有那么好说了。
@P2P: @Nekocross: 不过misakamm在网络上存在的时间要比breakwa11久得多，所以是读过了编程随想才更换ID的解释也是说得通的。
@Nekocross: 嗯，我也这样觉得。但是按照她自己的说法，完全是蓄意设置的虚假身份的话，也有些许牵强，因为实际上完全没有设置这样一个目标的必要。
@P2P: 说过。自己看到的是一个Twitter截图，当时没有保存，不过如果已经关注了她的Twitter的话应该可以找到。
@P2P: 其他话是指什么呢？自己不是很关注她，所以不是十分清楚。
@P2P: "我并不希望因为我自己的问题而害了另一个人“，看起来并不矛盾呀。
@P2P: 不过即便是存在矛盾，也只是说明了她的话不能全部相信而已。就过往的行为和作为代理软件开发者的身份而言，并不是一个不令人信服的假设吧。

@Binchan: No, the uploader downscales your images if they are too big, and JPG compression is *always* lossy. It tries to preserve image quality by using a Lanczos filter for downscaling instead of the (rather bad) Canvas default, but ultimately the point is to reduce file size for faster downloads. If you want to put original files there instead, you can put them into the site data folder manually, but then your site will be *huge* so there is always a tradeoff.

@Binchan: That is expected as JPG and PNG does compression in different ways. JPG uses FFT to truncate higher frequencies off, since those are harder to perceive for the human eye. The result is (usually) better quality for smaller file sizes, but it introduces those trademark artifacts, and doesn't handle sharp edges well. PNG uses entropy coding directly on bitmap data, so it can compress large flat areas well, until they're polluted by JPG's artifacts and are no longer flat. Fractal images are like the worst match for JPG (and most other lossy compression schemes as well).
Time to learn your moon runes!
If your setup is not too esoteric, there are installers that can automate the process for you. e.g. arch-anywhere
